title: Benjamin DesJardins
text: Benjamin DesJardins majors in Mathematics at SUNY Geneseo, with a focus on actuarial science. In his free time, Ben enjoys cooking, playing The Sims, and walking his two dogs.

title: Benjamin DesJardins
text:
Education
State University of New York at Geneseo | Geneseo, NY  B.A. in Mathematics | Jan 2023 - Dec 2024 
Jefferson Commnunity College | Watertown, NY  A.S. in Mathematics | Sep 2020 - Dec 2022

title: Benjamin DesJardins
text:
Experience
Watertown Savings Bank | Bank Teller | May 2023 - Present 
American Eagle Outfitters | Sales Associate | Jul 2021 - Present 
American Eagle Outfitters | Assistant Merchandise Team Leader | Apr 2022 - Jan 2023 
Jefferson Community College | Peer Tutor | Oct 2022 - Dec 2022

title: NFL in 2022
text:
Analyze the beer_markets.csv data.


Question 2

library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
NFL2022_stuffs <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_stuffs.csv')

Rows: 50147 Columns: 10
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): game_id, posteam
dbl (8): play_id, drive, week, qtr, down, half_seconds_remaining, pass, wp

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Q2a
In data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs, remove observations for which values of posteam is missing.

NFL2022_stuffs <- NFL2022_stuffs %>%
  filter(!is.na(posteam))



Q2b
Summarize the mean value of pass for each posteam when all the following conditions hold: wp is greater than 20% and less than 75%; down is less than or equal to 2; and half_seconds_remaining is greater than 120.

q2b <- NFL2022_stuffs %>% 
  filter(wp > .2 & wp <.75) %>% 
  filter(down <= 2) %>% 
  filter(half_seconds_remaining > 120) %>% 
  group_by(posteam) %>% 
  summarise(mean_pass = mean(pass))



Q2c
Provide both (1) a ggplot code with geom_point() using the resulting data.frame in Q2b and (2) a simple comments to describe the mean value of pass for each posteam. In the ggplot, reorder the posteam categories based on the mean value of pass in ascending or in descending order.

q2c <- q2b %>% 
  arrange(desc(mean_pass))

ggplot(q2c) + 
  geom_point(aes(x = reorder(posteam, -mean_pass), y = mean_pass))






Q2d

NFL2022_epa <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_epa.csv')

Rows: 46427 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): game_id, posteam, receiver, passer
dbl (3): play_id, drive, epa

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Create the data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs_EPA, that includes
All the variables in the data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs; The variables, passer, receiver, and epa, from the data.frame, NFL2022_epa. by joining the two data.frames. In the resulting data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs_EPA, remove observations with NA in passer.

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <- NFL2022_stuffs %>% 
  left_join(NFL2022_epa, by = "game_id")

Warning in left_join(., NFL2022_epa, by = "game_id"): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
â„¹ Row 1 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
â„¹ Row 1 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
â„¹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
  "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>%
  filter(!is.na(passer))



Q2e
Provide both (1) a single ggplot and (2) a simple comment to describe the NFL weekly trend of weekly mean value of epa for each of the following two passers, "J.Allen" "P.Mahomes"

passers <- c("J.Allen","P.Mahomes")
q2e <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  filter(passer %in% passers) %>% 
  group_by(passer, week) %>% 
  summarise(mean = mean(epa))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'passer'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

ggplot(q2e, aes(x = week, y = mean, color = passer)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point()




Overall, P.Mahomes has a higher average EPA for most weeks of the NFL. J.Allen has some of the lowest EPAâ€™s for each week.


Q2f
Calculate the difference between the mean value of epa for â€œJ.Allenâ€ the mean value of epa for â€œP.Mahomesâ€ for each value of week. ```

title: Beer Market
text:
Analyze the beer_markets.csv data.


library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
beer_mkts <- 
  read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/beer_markets.csv')

Rows: 73115 Columns: 24
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (13): _purchase_desc, brand, container, market, buyertype, income, age, ...
dbl  (5): hh, quantity, dollar_spent, beer_floz, price_per_floz
lgl  (6): promo, childrenUnder6, children6to17, microwave, dishwasher, singl...

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



Q1a
Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz. Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz of BUD LIGHT. Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz of BUSCH LIGHT. Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz of COORS LIGHT. Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz of MILLER LITE. Find the top 5 markets in terms of the total beer_floz of NATURAL LIGHT.

Q2a1 <- beer_mkts %>% 
   group_by(market) %>% 
   summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
   arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
   slice(1:5)

Q2a_bud <- beer_mkts %>% 
  filter(brand == "BUD LIGHT") %>% 
  group_by(market) %>% 
  summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
  arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
  slice(1:5)

Q2a_busch <- beer_mkts %>% 
  filter(brand == "BUSCH LIGHT") %>% 
  group_by(market) %>% 
  summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
  arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
  slice(1:5)

Q2a_coors <- beer_mkts %>% 
  filter(brand == "COORS LIGHT") %>% 
  group_by(market) %>% 
  summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
  arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
  slice(1:5)

Q2a_miller <- beer_mkts %>% 
  filter(brand == "MILLER LITE") %>% 
  group_by(market) %>% 
  summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
  arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
  slice(1:5)

Q2a_natural <- beer_mkts %>% 
  filter(brand == "NATURAL LIGHT") %>% 
  group_by(market) %>% 
  summarize(beer_floz_tot = sum(beer_floz, na.rm = T)) %>% 
  arrange(-beer_floz_tot) %>% 
  slice(1:5)



Q2b
For households that purchased BUD LIGHT at least once, what fraction of households did purchase only BUD LIGHT?
For households that purchased BUSCH LIGHT at least once, what fraction of households did purchase only BUSCH LIGHT?
For households that purchased COORS LIGHT at least once, what fraction of households did purchase only COORS LIGHT?
For households that purchased MILLER LITE at least once, what fraction of households did purchase only MILLER LITE?
For households that purchased NATURAL LIGHT at least once, what fraction of households did purchase only NATURAL LIGHT?
Which beer brand does have the largest proportion of such loyal consumers?

q2b <- beer_mkts %>% 
  mutate(bud = ifelse(brand=="BUD LIGHT", 1, 0), # 1 if brand=="BUD LIGHT"; 0 otherwise
         busch = ifelse(brand=="BUSCH LIGHT", 1, 0),
         coors = ifelse(brand=="COORS LIGHT", 1, 0),
         miller = ifelse(brand=="MILLER LITE", 1, 0),
         natural = ifelse(brand=="NATURAL LIGHT", 1, 0),
         .after = hh) %>% 
  select(hh:natural) %>%  # select the variables we need
  group_by(hh) %>% 
  summarise(n_transactions = n(), # number of beer transactions for each hh
            n_bud = sum(bud), # number of BUD LIGHT transactions for each hh
            n_busch = sum(busch), 
            n_coors = sum(coors), 
            n_miller = sum(miller), 
            n_natural = sum(natural) 
  ) %>% 
  summarise(loyal_bud = sum(n_transactions == n_bud) / sum(n_bud > 0), 
              # sum(n_transactions == n_bud) : the number of households that purchased BUD LIGHT only
              # sum(n_bud > 0) : the number of households that purchased BUD LIGHT at least once.
            loyal_busch = sum(n_transactions == n_busch) / sum(n_busch > 0),
            loyal_coors = sum(n_transactions == n_coors) / sum(n_coors > 0),
            loyal_miller = sum(n_transactions == n_miller) / sum(n_miller > 0),
            loyal_natural = sum(n_transactions == n_natural) / sum(n_natural > 0)
  )



Q2c
For each household, calculate the number of beer transactions. For each household, calculate the proportion of each beer brand choice.

q2c <- beer_mkts %>% 
  count(hh, brand) %>% 
  group_by(hh) %>% 
  mutate(n_tot = sum(n)) %>%  # n_tot : the number of beer transactions
  arrange(hh, brand) %>% 
  mutate( prop = n / n_tot ) # prop: the proportion of each beer brand choice

title: NYC Restaurant Inspection
text:
Analyze the DOHMH_NYC_Restaurant_Inspection.csv data.


library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
restaurant <- 
  read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/DOHMH_NYC_Restaurant_Inspection.csv')

Rows: 17633 Columns: 12
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (10): DBA, BORO, STREET, CUISINE DESCRIPTION, INSPECTION DATE, ACTION, V...
dbl  (2): CAMIS, SCORE

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


#Q1a) What are the mean, standard deviation, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum of SCORE for each GRADE of restaurants?

scorePerGrade <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(restaurant$GRADE) %>%
  summarize(
    score_mean = mean(SCORE),
    score_sd = sd(SCORE),
    score_min = min(SCORE),
    score_q1 = quantile(SCORE, probs = .25),
    score_median = median(SCORE),
    score_q1 = quantile(SCORE, probs = .75),
    score_max = max(SCORE) )

#Q1b) How many restaurants with a GRADE of A are there in NYC? How much percentage of restaurants in NYC are a GRADE of C?

numObs <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(GRADE) %>% 
  summarize( number = n())

16305 with a grade of A

294 / sum(numObs$number) * 100 

[1] 1.667328


Percentage with grade C
#Q1c)
Provide both (1) ggplot code and (2) a simple comment to describe how the distribution of SCORE varies by GRADE and CRITICAL FLAG.

ggplot( data = restaurant) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = SCORE, fill = restaurant$`CRITICAL FLAG`), bins = 50) +
  facet_grid(. ~ GRADE)




Critical makes up the majority of each grade, and those with the grade A has the highest and most varied scores, those with grade C have much larger scores
#Q1d) Provide both (1) ggplot code and (2) a simple comment to describe how the proportion of CRITICAL FLAG varies by GRADE and BORO.

ggplot(data = restaurant) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = GRADE, fill = BORO)) +
  facet_wrap(. ~ `CRITICAL FLAG`)




Staten Island and Bronx make up the smallest proportions of boroughs.
Manhattan makes up the largest proportion of each grade. Critical and Not Critical have very similar distributions.
#Q1e) For the 10 most common CUISINE DESCRIPTION values, find the CUISINE DESCRIPTION value that has the highest proportion of GRADE A.

cuiseDescrip <-  restaurant %>% 
  group_by(`CUISINE DESCRIPTION`) %>%
  summarise(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-count) %>% 
  mutate()

head(cuiseDescrip, 10)

# A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
   `CUISINE DESCRIPTION`    count
   <chr>                    <int>
 1 American                  3678
 2 Coffee/Tea                1414
 3 Chinese                   1372
 4 Pizza                     1050
 5 Italian                    689
 6 Bakery Products/Desserts   615
 7 Japanese                   584
 8 Mexican                    582
 9 Latin American             544
10 Donuts                     505


#Q1f) Find the 3 most common names of restaurants (DBA) in each BORO. If the third most common DBA values are multiple, please include all the DBA values.

q2f <- restaurant %>% 
  select(DBA, BORO) %>% 
  group_by(BORO, DBA) %>% 
  summarize(n = n()) %>% 
  mutate(ranking = dense_rank(-n)) %>% 
  filter(ranking <= 3) %>% 
  arrange(BORO, ranking)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'BORO'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

q2f_ <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(DBA) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(-n)

#Q1g) For all the DBA values that appear in the result of Q1f, find the DBA value that is most likely to commit critical violation.

q2g <- restaurant %>% 
  filter(DBA %in% q2f$DBA) %>% 
  group_by(DBA, `CRITICAL FLAG`) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  group_by(DBA) %>% 
  mutate(lag_n = lag(n),
         tot = sum(n),
         prop_crit = lag_n / tot) %>% 
  select(DBA, prop_crit) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(prop_crit)) %>% 
  arrange(-prop_crit)

title: Spotify Data
text:
Analyze the spotify_all.csv data.


library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
spotify_all <- 
  read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/spotify_all.csv')

Rows: 198005 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): playlist_name, artist_name, track_name, album_name
dbl (3): pid, pos, duration_ms

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



Q1a
Find the top 10 most popular songs

Q1a <- spotify_all %>% 
  count(artist_name, track_name) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  head(10)



Q1b
Find the five most popular artist in terms of the number of occurrences in the data.frame, spotify_all What is the most popular song for each of the five most popular artist?

Q1b <- spotify_all %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_artist = n()) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate( artist_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_artist) ) ) %>% 
  filter( artist_ranking <= 5) %>% 
  group_by(artist_name, track_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_track = n()) %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(track_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_track) ) ) %>% 
  filter( track_ranking <= 2) %>%   # I just wanted to see the top two tracks for each artist
  select(artist_name, artist_ranking, n_popular_artist, track_name, track_ranking, n_popular_track) %>% 
  distinct() %>% 
  arrange(artist_ranking, track_ranking)



Q1C
Provide both (1) ggplot codes and (2) a couple of sentences to describe the relationship between pos and the ten most popular artists.

Q1c <- spotify_all %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_artist = n()) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate( artist_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_artist) ) ) %>% 
  filter( artist_ranking <= 10) 
  
# boxplot
ggplot(Q1c,
       aes(x = pos, y = fct_reorder(artist_name, -artist_ranking)) ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(
    fun = mean,
    color = 'red'
  )

Warning: Removed 10 rows containing missing values (`geom_segment()`).






# histogram
ggplot(Q1c) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = pos), binwidth = 1) + 
  facet_grid(fct_reorder(artist_name, artist_ranking) ~ .  , switch = "y") +
  theme(strip.text.y.left = element_text(angle = 0))

title: DANL Project
section: 2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
text:
2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
The following boxplot shows how the distribution of highway MPG (hwy) varies by a type of cars (class) ğŸš™ ğŸšš ğŸš.

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy, fill = class),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = "Class", y = "Highway\nMPG")

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
oj <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dominick_oj.csv')
nvars <- format(round(ncol(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",") 
nobs <- format(round(nrow(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",")
The number of variables is 4; the number of observations is 28,947.
Roses are red
violets are blue.

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.1 Data Summary

Summary statistics (Use skimr::skim())

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.2 Data Visualization

oj %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = log(sales), 
             y = log(price),
             color = brand)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .1) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = F) +
  facet_wrap(.~ad) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(legend.position = 'top')

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.3 Data Transformation

ob_sum1 <- oj %>% 
  group_by(brand, ad) %>% 
  summarise(sales_tot = sum(sales, na.rm = T),
            price_mean = round(mean(price, na.rm = T), 2))
